Award.AwardTitle: NURTURES: Networking Urban Resources with Teachers and University to enRich Early Childhood Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
NURTURES (Networking Urban Resources with Teachers and University to enRich Early Childhood Science) is creating an integrated system of science education for grades preschool through 3 (PK-3) in the Toledo, Ohio area. The University of Toledo (UT) Judith Herb College of Education and College of Engineering in collaboration with the College of Arts and Sciences at UT and Toledo Public Schools (TPS) along with supporting educational partners (Apple Tree Nursery School, the East Toledo Family Center Day Care, the Toledo Day Nursery, Olivet Nursery, Fairgreen Nursery, the Toledo Catholic Schools, informal science partners (UT Ritter Planetarium, Imagination Station, Toledo Zoo, Toledo Metropark System, Toledo Botanical Gardens, Toledo Grows, Lourdes College Nature Laboratory, and the Challenger Learning Center) and community resources (YMCA, Boys and Girls Club, Lucas County Library, and WGTE Public Broadcasting Station) are working to transform the way in which PK-3 science is taught through the development and implementation of a complementary science education learning model that combines inquiry and learning, formal and informal education, teachers and parents, schools and the community, in a comprehensive effort to improve science subject interest and science achievement. Primary objectives include: increased student interest and achievement in science, increased PK-3 teachers' knowledge of science pedagogy and science standards, increased parent involvement in in-school and out-of-school educational activities, a replicable complementary science education learning model, and increased state, district and school policies supporting PK-3 science education and parent involvement. The project includes summer institutes, academic year support for teachers, and parent support. University faculty, master PK-3 teachers, and informal science educators are developing a summer institute to provide professional development in challenging inquiry-based, age appropriate science instruction integrated with reading and math and professional development and practice in engaging families in formal and informal education. Teacher participants create their own lessons that include family learning activities. Formal and family science learning are augmented by annual community science events hosted by the informal science partners and linked to the TPS science curriculum and Ohio Content Standards. The project is providing science education professional development to 495 PK-3 teachers and their principals or directors working in at least 50 community-based early care and education programs and 300 K-3 classrooms.

NURTURES is investigating the feasibility of the complementary science learning model in a mid-sized urban location as well as how complementary learning might affect student achievement, curiosity, and interest in science. It is examining the impact of the scientists' and engineers' involvement on PK-3 science teaching and learning - an area where little research has been conducted. It is also determining the types of supports needed to ensure that PK-3 teachers implement inquiry-based science as well as the supports needed to encourage parents to make use of family science activities. The results of these investigations will be a stimulating educational environment for young children that nurtures their natural curiosity to learn science and to continue to study science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the NURTURES program was to transform the way in which PK-3 science is taught through the development and implementation of a complementary science education learning model that combines inquiry and learning, formal and informal education, teachers and parents, schools and the community, in a comprehensive effort to improve science subject interest and sustained science achievement. The work of NURTURES focused on three main outcomes:  

1)   Alignment of teachers’ instructional practices with A Framework for K-12 Science Education [Framework][1]

2)   Improvement in the quality of family interactions while learning science together

3)   Increase in science proficiency in children in PK-3         

The NURTURES program successfully demonstrated a complementary learning model of science that incorporated teacher professional development, family engagement and community resources within the Toledo, OH area. Spanning the time period between July, 2011 and December 2017, NURTURES provided 544 hours of science professional development to 329 PK-3 teacher and administrator participants from 79 facilities throughout the greater Toledo area. Of these participants, 105 participated in the program for two or more years. This professional development included an intensive two-week Summer Institute, as well as academic year professional development through both Professional Learning Communities and one-to-one coaching support. Daily in the Summer Institute, teachers experienced a high-quality inquiry lesson and a metacognitive session, where they delved further into aspects of the Framework (science and engineering practices, core science ideas, and crosscutting concepts). Teachers also developed their own Framework-aligned lessons.

In addition, NURTURES provided high-quality science engagement opportunities to families. Project-designed Family Pack Activities were sent home once per quarter to students in classrooms of participating teachers. These activities and materials were designed to be age-appropriate, engaging activities that incorporated science and engineering practices, cross-cutting concepts and core science ideas with the intent to allow families to explore, discuss, and think together. The Family Packs reached an estimated 11,675 families. NURTURES also partnered with area informal science facilities (e.g., The Toledo Zoo, Imagination Station, Metroparks Toledo) and community resources (e.g., Toledo Lucas County Public Library, the YMCA) to hold Sci-FUN events, which were community science events, throughout the academic year. Activities highlighted programming of our partners interfused with questions and discussion points to facilitate scientific discourse among families. Overall, 1,359 families (2,191 adults and 2,747 children) attended these events. Ten one-minute science segments that encouraged family science activities were created and aired for 1,350 placements on the local PBS station during children’s programming times.

The NURTURES program positively impacted teacher knowledge of core science ideas, showing gains through the use of concept map analysis. Teacher science instructional changes were measured through the Systematic Characterization of Inquiry Instruction in Early Classroom Environments (SCIIENCE), a project-created instrument that uses a combination of global and frequency codes to identify teacher instructional practices aligned with the Framework to elicit scientific and engineering practices from students[2]. To test the NURTURES teachers’ impact on student learning, we analyzed data from the 2013-14, 2014-15 and 2015-16 Renaissance STAR Reading, Math, and Early Literacy exams. STAR is a computer-adaptive diagnostic assessment from Renaissance Learning. Toledo Public School students take the STAR Math and Reading assessments three times per academic year during grades 2-8, and the STAR Early Literacy assessment in K-1. A teacher’s participation in NURTURES improved students’ scores in a statistically significant manner on Renaissance STAR assessments compared with those students whose teachers had not participated in NURTURES: Early Literacy by a small amount, Math by a moderate amount, and Reading by a large amount (0.25 student standard deviations, a substantively important amount).

The success of the NURTURES program in the Toledo area was demonstrated through the positive impact on academic achievement in early literacy, reading and mathematics in PK-3 students. This model will be used in areas outside the Toledo area to determine its impact on science achievement, as well as to understand the additive component of family involvement in high-quality science.

[1] National Research Council. (2012). A framework for K-12 science education: Practices, crosscutting concepts, and core ideas. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press.

[2] Paprzycki, P., Tuttle, N. Czerniak, C. M., Molitor, S., Kaderavek, J., and Mendenhall, R. (2017). The impact of a Framework-aligned science professional development program on literacy and mathematics achievement of K-3 students. Journal of Research in Science Teaching. DOI: 10.1002/tea.21400. http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/tea.21400.
